flashcards.english: Ko ko ko (knock sound), Nũũ? (who is it?), Nĩĩ nĩĩ (it is me), Nĩĩ we ũ? (who are you?), Njĩtagwo Njeri (my name is Njeri), Njeri wa ũ? (whose Njeri/who's your father?), Njeri wa Njoroge (Njeri of Njoroge), Wee wĩ mũgeni (you are a visitor), Ĩĩ nđĩ mũgeni (yes I am a visitor), Ingĩra (enter), Nyua cai (take tea), Nĩĩ nđainuka (I am off home), Thĩĩ na wega (go in peace)
flashcards.notes: Complete visitor arrival conversation showing traditional greeting customs. Note cultural pattern: asking lineage (Njeri wa ũ? = whose Njeri?). Ko ko ko represents door knocking sound

flashcards.english: Mũirĩtu ũyũ (this girl), Aĩrĩtu aya (these girls), Ũyũ nũũ? (who is this?), Aya nĩ a? (who are these?), Etagwo atĩa? (what is his/her name?), Nĩ waragia gĩkũyũ? (do you speak Kikuyu?), Aria na nĩĩ (speak to me)
flashcards.notes: Common identification and question patterns. Additional vocabulary: Mbũkũ (rabbit), Nguru (tortoise). Demonstrates this/these distinction: ũyũ (this singular) vs aya (these plural)

flashcards.english: Nĩĩtũcemanie (let's meet), Ũkwenda tũcemanie kũ? (where do you want us to meet?), Nĩ tũcemanie mũkawainĩ (let us meet at a hotel), Mũkawa ũrikũ? (which hotel?), Ũria wĩtagwo 'Springs' (the one called Springs), Ndiũĩ (I don't know it), Haica matatu ya taũnĩ (board a matatu to town), Wakinĩya ũhũrĩre thimũ (when you arrive call me by phone), Taũnĩ nĩ nene (the town is large), Ngumĩra kũ? (where do I disembark?), Ũmĩra bothita (disembark at Posta/Post office)
flashcards.notes: Complete conversation about arranging a meeting and giving directions. Modern vocabulary: matatu (minibus), thimũ (phone). Shows subjunctive use: Nĩĩtũcemanie (let's meet), Wakinĩya (when you arrive)
